fields: Relating to or affecting an organs function

What are the parenchymal cells of the liver?
What percentage of liver cells do they make up?
The four non-parenchymal cells of the liver are {{c1::Sinusoidal endothelial cells (lsecs), Biliary epithelial cells (cholagiocytes),Kupffer cells, Hepatic stellate cells (HSC)}}
LSECs are very thin cells with no {{c1::basement membrane}} and many {{c1::fenestrae}}

Biliary epithelial cells function as {{c1::cuboidal epithelium}} in small interlobar bile ducts, and as {{c1::columnar and mucus secreting cells}} in larger bile ducts. 

They secrete {{c1::bicarbonate}} and {{c1::water}} which contributes to bile.
What is the role of Kupffer cells?
What can heme be broken down into?
Quiescient HSC is a storage site for {{c1::vitamin A}}. When activated, they become {{c1::contractile}} and produce {{c1::extra-cellular matrix proteins}}
At what blood pressure is it considered portal hypertension?
What does alcohol increase the intestines permeability of?
Endotoxins (lipopolysacchrides), components of the gram negative bacterial cell wall.
What cytokines can kupffer cells produce?
Why aren't the hepatic arteries really affected by fibrosis of the liver?

What is normal portal pressure?
What is portal hypertension?
How much of the blood flow to the liver comes from the portal vein?
{{c1::glucagon}} is an endogenous vasodilator, produced in the the {{c1::pancreas}} that would usually be inactivated by the {{c1::liver}}
What happens to the heart as a result of all the new volume?
Increased EDV, which menas heart is stretched
What veins do the esophageal varices anastamose with?
Veins that drain into the azygous vein
What hormone contributes to biliary epithelial cell fluid secretion?
Why might an esophageal varix rupture?
Thin walls dues to stretch, and food passing down.
What is a fall in portal vein blood flow offset by?
An increase in hepatic artery blood flow
What hormones/neurotransmitters are in abundance during cirrhosis?
What drug would you give to reduce the effect of portal hypertension?
Propranolol or any other beta blokcer
What receptor is used to reduce the splanchnic blood flow?
What is the most common route of membrane passage for a drug?

The four physiochemical factors are 
{{c1::Molecular size}}

{{c1::Solubility at site of absorption}}

{{c1::Degree of ionization}}

{{c1::Relative lipid solubility of unionized and ionized forms}}

Smaller drugs=easier to absorb
Drugs that are not soluble=not absorbed
Drugs with ionic charge not absorbed

Rate of diffusion proportional to
{{c1::Magnitude of concentration gradient}} and
{{c1::Lipid:water partition, i.e. lipid solubility}}

{{c1::Non-polar}} or {{c1::ionized}} molecules are essentially impermeable to the cell membrane

Lipophilic drugs are filtered into urine but readily reabsorbed
How do we eliminate them?

Biotransformation into less lipophilic compounds
Decreases activity
Aids elimination in the kidney

Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor
Prednisone is an oral corticosteroid

Drug metabolizing enzymes expressed
highly in {{c1::Liver}} and {{c1::Small intestinal epithelial cells}}

Orally administered drugs are absorbed through small intestinal
epithelial cells and  travel in {{c1::portal vein}} to liver.
The drugs undergo significant biotransformation prior to reaching {{c1::systemic circulation}}
Hepatocytes work on the blood in the sinusoids, non-orally administered drugs avoid First-pass metabolism

phase 1 usually results in drugs with lower pharm activity
phase 2 usually produce more polar drugs and are excreted in kidney

{{c1::CYP1}}Primarily metabolize carcinogens, some drugs as well
{{c1::CYP2}}Metabolize many important drugs
{{c1::CYP3}}Most abundant family in human liver, metabolize many important drugs
Promoters of genes encoding certain CYPs respond to {{c1::certain drugs}} and {{c1::pollutants}}.
Induction of CYP can lead to an increase in detoxifying activity or an increase in toxic metabolites, depending on what's being metabolised.
An aryl hydrocarbons is a harmful {{c1::xenobiotic}} substance.

Most CYPs have activity against multiple substrates

co-administration of 2 substrates for one {{c1::CYP}} results in competition
Drug with lower {{c1::affinity}} is metabolized more slowly
Name an non comprtitive inhibitor of a CYP

Phase 2 reactions.
Catalyzed by a diverse group of enzymes {{c1::
(transferases)
}}
Transfer of "simple" moieties (methyl-, acetyl-, sulfate, etc.) to a
{{c1::heteroatom}} (N, O or S) on the target drug

Enzymatic activation of these common intermediates to high-
energy species which then serve as co-substrates for the
transferases
Most, but not all, of these reaction products are extremely polar.

Increased water solubility of most conjugates makes them readily
excreted in the urine

{{c1::Fulminant}} hepatic failure is the rapid development of severe acute liver injury with
impaired synthetic function and {{c1::encephalopathy}} in a person
who previously had a normal liver
Usually < 8 weeks, sometimes , 1 week

Fulminant Hepatic Failure: Causes

{{c1::paracetamol overdose}} (39 percent)

indeterminate (17 percent)

idiosyncratic (non-acetaminophen) drug reactions (13
percent)

{{c1::viral hepatitis A or B}} (12 percent)

Rare Causes:
Autoimmune hepatitis
{{c1::Wilson's Disease}}: Overload of copper in the liver
{{c1::Budd Chiari}}: Acute obstruction of hepatic vein
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
{{c1::Nimesulide}} caused an idiosyncratic drug reaction that led to fulminant liver failure, that led to it being pulled from use

Hepatic Encephalopathy: Failure to {{c1::detoxify}} portal blood

{{c1::Ammonia}} in the blood is a good indicator of fulminant liver failure.

Clinical Faetures of encephalopathy are:
Confusion
Drosziness
{{c1::COnstructional Apraxia}}: inability to assemble, draw objects
{{c1::Fetor hepaticus}}: Bad breath

{{c1::2}}: Gross disorientation, drowsiness, possibly asterixis,
inappropriate behavior

{{c1::1}} Changes in behavior with minimal change in level of
consciousness

{{c1::4}}Comatose, unresponsive to pain, decorticate or
decerebrate posturing

 {{c1::3}}Marked confusion, incoherent speech, sleeping most of
the time but arousable to vocal stimuli
Why does fluid oedema happen during fulminant liver failure?

Osmotic changes in astrocytes (big differrence in osmotic pressure between brain and plasma)

Fluid balance, elevate head, mannitol are treatments

Liver produces clotting factors {{c1::2,7,9,10}}(4)
They are all {{c1::vitamin k}} depedant
In liver failure there is a decreased ability to synthesize clotting factors.
This can result in bleeding, especially in  {{c1::GI tract.}}
Treatment: replace clotting factors

Paracetamol Toxicity:
{{c1::50%}} Accidental Overdose ,{{c1::50%}} suicide

Paracetamol toxicity is a common cause of {{c1::fulminant hepatic failure}}

Dose: 
 Toxicity unlikely < {{c1::10g}} in adults 
 Toxicity almost universal > {{c1::20g}} in adults 
 1 Panadol tablet = 500mg paracetamol
this is the new and improved nomogram

Clinical Features of Paracetamol Intoxication:

First 24 hours 
 {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting
 Malaise 
 Labs results are {{c1::normal}} 

24-72 hours 
 Elevated 
   -{{c1::aminotransferase}}: Due to degradation of hepatocytes
   -{{c1::bilirubin}}: Due to degradation of hemoglobin
   -{{c1::prothrombin time}}: Due to absence of clotting factors             2,7,9,10
 RUQ pain 
 {{c1::Renal}} failure

72-96 hours 
 {{c1::Jaundice}}: Due to build u of bilirubin 
 {{c1::Encephalopathy}}: Due to liver not working anymore
 Worsening liver and renal function

 > 96 hours 
 Death 
 Liver transplant 
 Slow recovery
Serum Creatinine can be an indicator of renal failure

Treatment of paracetamol intoxication:

Gastrointestinal decontamination: 
{{c1::Activated charcoal}} (adsorbing agent)
If < {{c1::4}} hours since ingestion 
Longer if delayed-release tabs used 

Antidotes
Drug Name: {{c1::N-acetylcysteine}} 
 Precursor of {{c1::glutathione}} 
 Increases {{c1::glutathione}} stores 
 Neutralizes {{c1::NAPQI}} 
 Anti-{{c1::inflammatory}} & anti-{{c1::oxidant}} properties 
 Highly efficacious

Indications for NAC

-Serum paracetamol concentration drawn at 4 hours or more after a single acute ingestion is above the "possible hepatic toxicity" line of the Rumack-Matthew nomogram

-Serum paracetamol concentration is unavailable or will not return within {{c1::8}} hours of time of ingestion and paracetamol ingestion suspected

-{{c1::Time}} of ingestion is unknown and serum paracetamol level is greater than {{c1::10}} micrograms/ml

-There is evidence of ANY {{c1::hepatotoxicity}} with a history of paracetamol ingestion

-Patient reports or clinician suspects {{c1::repeated}} excessive paracetamol ingestions, patient has risk factors for paracetamol -induced hepatotoxicity, and the serum paracetamol level is greater than 10 micrograms/mL
New nomogram, and you use treatment line now, which is 25% lower than possible hepatic toxicity line.

N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI) 
 Highly {{c1::reactive}} electrophile 
 Covalently binds {{c1::hepatocyte}} macromolecules. Covalent means bond is {{c1::Irreversible}}
 Can cause {{c1::Oxidative}} injury 
 {{c1::Centrilobular}} necrosis 
 Secondary release of {{c1::cytokines}} and {{c1::ROS}}

MELD Score
MELD Score = (0.957 * ln({{c1::Serum Cr}}) + 0.378 * ln({{c1::Serum Bilirubin}}) + 1.120 * ln({{c1::INR}}) + 0.643 ) * 10

Sensory Inputs to Respiratory Centre

Central {{c1::Chemoreceptors}} and Peripheral {{c1::Chemoreceptors}}(Both the same): Monitor PCO2

Higher Brain Centres: When we conciously breath

Pulmonary {{c1::Stretch}} Receptors: Monitors over or underbreathing

Muscle Stretch Receptors: These activate during excercise to help adjust ventilation

Irritant Receptors: Important in the {{c1::cough}} and {{c1::sneeze}}  reflex

• O2 binds to Hb with much {{c1::less}} affinity than carbon monoxide

Normal Lung
• Cappilary PO2 equilibrates with {{c1::Alveolar}} PO2 after {{c1::0.25}} seconds
{{c1::97}}% of oxygen that diffuses into capillary binds to Hb
In healthy Lung Oxygen Transfer is {{c1::Perfusion}} Limited


Abnormal Lung with Thickened barrier
• {{c1::Diffusion}} is impaired
• Capillary PO2 may not equilibrate with {{c1::Alveolar}} PO2
In non - healthy Lung Oxygen Transfer is {{c1::Diffusion}} limited

Excercise {{c1::increases}} the amount of time taken for oxygen to diffuse

Where is the best ventilation in the lung? Apex/Base  {{c1::Base}}
Where is the best perfusion in the lung? APex/Base {{c1::Base}}

Measurement of regional differences in ventilation is measured using {{c1::radioactive xenon}} (substance marker)

Pulmonary blood flow is much higher at base/apex due to {{c1::gravity}}         {{c1::base}}

Zone 1 (APEX OF LUNG)
• {{c1::Alveolar}} pressure higher than {{c1::Pulmonary artery}} Pressure & {{c1::venous}} Pressure, so collapsible vessels closed and no flow

• Zone 2 (middle of lung)
• {{c1::Pulmonary artery}} pressure > {{c1::Alveolar }} pressure > {{c1::venous}} pressure. 
Constriction at the downstream end of collapsible vessel.
Intermittent flow with each breath

• Zone 3
• (Pulmonary artery) pressure > (venous) pressure > (Alveolar) pressure , and so collapsible vessels are held open
From the Apex to base of the lung ventilation decreases {{c1::less}} quickly than perfusion

{{c1::Deadspace}} : High ventilation, low perfusion
{{c1::Shunt}}:  Low ventilation, high perfusion

Shunt and deadspace can lead to hypoxia
Shunt
• Perfusion of lung units without ventilation
• Unoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation
• V/Q = 0

• Dead space
• Ventilation of lung units without perfusion
• Gas enters and leaves lung units without contacting blood
• Wasted ventilation
• V/Q is infinite

Flow= Pressure{{c1::/}} Resistance

At low flow rates, flow is {{c1::laminar}}
At higher flow rates (esp. at branches etc.) flow is {{c1::turbulent}}

Most resistance (and turbulent flow) is in {{c1::medium}} sized bronchi 
{{c1::Terminal}} bronchioles offer very little resistance

In upper airway obstruction, development of {{c1::turbulent}} flow is important mechanism of increased airway resistance
 
Treated by {{c1::Heliox}} (21 % O2 , 79 % He) 
{{c1::Less}} dense than air so more conducive to laminar flow and ↓ resistance in turbulent flow


Factors Affecting Airway Resistance 
• Lung Volume:

Increased Lung volume= {{c1::decreased}} Airway resistance and {{c1::increased}} Bronchi diameter  

Decreased Lung volume= {{c1::increased}} Airway resistance 
Small airways (base of lung) may close completely 


Factors Affecting Airway Resistance 
• Bronchial smooth muscle contraction ↓ airway diameter ↑ resistance 
 Due to {{c1::Vagus}}nerve and {{c1::ACh}} (NT) and Irritant reflexes 

• Bronchial smooth muscle relaxation ↑ airway diameter ↓ resistance
 • Activation of {{c1::adrenergic}} receptors

Oxygen consumption:
~ {{c1::250}}ml/min (approximately 3 – 4ml/kg/min)

Oxygen delivery:
~ {{c1::1000}}ml/min (~ 10 – 15ml/Kg/min)

Oxygen delivery
DO2 = CO {{c1::x}} CaO2
CO={{c1::Cardiac Output}}
CaO2=Oxygen content of arterial blood

CaO2 =({{c1::Hb}} x 1.34 x SaO2/100) + 0.0225 PaO2 (Kpa)

0.0225 PaO2 (Kpa) is the amount of oxygen {{c1::dissolved}} in the blood

Elevated CO2 levels lead to respiratory {{c1::acidosis}}
{{c1::hypercapnea}}: Build up of CO2 in bloodstream

Elevated CO2 levels can cause vasodilation of vessels in the brain, causing cerebral oedema

Can also cause heart to pump less efficiantly, this can lead to ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Respiratory Failure.

Type 1:
 {{c1::Oxygenation}} failure which leads to {{c1::hypoxia}} (in the slides)
PaO2 must be under {{c1::60}}mmHg to be considered type 1 resp failure (normal is {{c1::100}}mmHg)

Type 2: 
{{c1::Ventilation}} failure which leads to {{c1::hypercapneoa}}
PaCO2 is over {{c1::50}}mmHg for type 2 resp failure (normal is {{c1::40}}mmHg)
It is associated with {{c1::acidosis}}

Which is more life threatening: Acute Hypoxia or CO2 retention? {{c1::Hypoxia}}

If patient comes in with hypoxia, if you give too much O2, body can start hypoventilating causing retention of CO2.

Type 2 common in COPD and Pickwickian syndrome

CAUSES OF RESPIRATORY FAILURE
- Airways:
Acinus which consists of {{c1::respiratory bronchioles/alveoli}}
Pulmonary blood supply

- Neurological system
CNS: 
{{c1::carotid body}} chemoreceptors,
respiratory center

PNS: 
Innervation to {{c1::neuromuscular junctions}}

- muscles of respiration;
{{c1::diaphragm, intercostals,
accessory muscles}}(3)

Airway Conditions
{{c1::- Asthma, 
-COPD
- Pneumonia
-Pulmonary oedema
- Pulmonary embolism}} (5)

- Overdose ({{c1::opiates}}, {{c1::benzodiazeplines}})
-{{c1::brain-stem}} stroke

Muscle Affecting Conditions
{{c1::MND, 
Guillain-Barre,
myasthenia gravis,
Muscular dystrophy}}

The {{c1::phrenic}} nerve supplies the diaphragm
The {{c1::intercostal}} nerve supplies the intercostal muscles

Impulses from peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors are carried by the {{c1::glossopharyngeal}} nerve and {{c1::vagus}} nerve to the respiratory center

Asthma,Cancer of the airway ,Foreign body are all examples of {{c1::intrinsic}} ariway obstruction

Infections of the epiglottis or neck, goitre are examples of {{c1::extrinsic}} airway obstruction

Supportive or definitive treatment?

Priority is to support respiratory function {{c1::supportive}}

Involves establishing the underlying cause of the illness {{c1::definitive}}

Commence before definitive diagnosis {{c1::supportive}}

Buys time {{c1::supportive}}

requires history, physical examination and investigations {{c1::definitve}}

Conditions: Bronchoconstriction, Tumour, Infection, Foreign body

Intubation and resection treats {{c1::a tumour}}

Removal treats {{c1::foreign body}}

Intubation and antibiotic treats {{c1::infection}}

B-agonists, Steroids treat, {{c1::bronchoconstriction}}

Dead space is when a lung is being {{c1::ventialted}} but not {{c1::perfused}}

Anatomical dead space makes up {{c1::1/3}} of tidal volume

Anatomical dead space does does not include {{c1::alveoli}}

Physiological dead space is any part of the lung not being perfused

Shunt is when a lung is {{c1::perfused}} but not {{c1::ventilated}}

Examples of conditions that involeve alveolar consolidation are {{c1::pneumonia, ARDS, and cardiac failure}}(3) due to Pus ,Inflammatory exudate and pulmonary oedema respectively

Examples of conditions that involve impaired diffusion are {{c1:: Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis Cancer}}(2) dues to fibrous tissue and malignant cells respectively

A-a Gradient (difference in PAO2 and PaO2)
Normal gradient:
{{c1::5 – 10}}mmHg

Hypoxia + normal gradient:
Implies {{c1::hypoventilation}}

Hypoxia + increased gradient:
Implies {{c1::intrapulmonary shunt}}
70 X 70 = 5 L/min is nromal I think

3 Determinants of Stroke Volume:
{{c1::Preload}}: Initial Stretching of myocytes prior to contraction
{{c1::Afterload}}: Force against which heart has to contract to eject blood
{{c1::Contractility}}

Baroreceptors are connected to the {{c1::autonomic nervous system}} control centers in the {{c1::brain stem}}


When intravascular volume is high, baroreceptors are {{c1::stretched}}, therefore they cause:
Inhibition of the {{c1::sympathetic}} system
Activation of the {{c1::parasympathetic}} system

This causes
 -vaso{{c1::dilation}}
 -{{c1::decreased}} heart rate
 -{{c1::decreased}} cardiac contractility
Look I could do another card but it is the exact opposite for hypovolemia

RENIN-ANGIOTENSIN SYSTEM:

{{c1::Angiotensinogen}} converted by {{c1::Renin}} (made in {{c1::kidneys}}) to {{c1::Angiotensin 1}}, convertd by {{c1::ACE}} (found in {{c1::lungs}}) to {{c1::Angiotensin 2}}

Stimuli for secretion of renin
–{{c1::Decreased}} pressure at the {{c1::afferent}} arteriole
- Sympathetic activation (beta1)

Both happen during {{c1::hypovolaemia}}

Effects of angiotensin II

– Arteriolar {{c1::vasoconstriction}}
(hence ↑ {{c1::MAP}}) and decreased {{c1::GFR}}

– Stimulation of {{c1::aldosterone}} secretion
(hence ↑ {{c1::plasma volume}})

– Na+ {{c1::reabsorption}} by the {{c1::proximal tubule}}


– Thirst ({{c1::subfornical organ}})

When intravascular volume is {{c1::low}}, the renin-angiotensin (and aldosterone) system is activated.

This helps to:
1. {{c1::maintain blood pressure}}
2. {{c1::retain volume}}

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
-also known as {{c1::vassopressin}}

Mainly regulates {{c1::osmolarity}}
Also released when loss of blood volume is {{c1::>10%}}

Effects
– {{c1::Vasoconstriction}}
– {{c1::Reasorption}} of water from {{c1::distal tubule}} and {{c1::collecting duct}}
In hypovolemic patients a decrease in {{c1::cardiac preload}} causes a decrease in SV

Hypovolemic patient
Compensatory mechanisms:
1.Activation of the {{c1::sympathetic nervous system}}
2.Activation of the {{c1::renin-angiotensin system}}
3.Release of {{c1::aldosterone}}
4.Release of {{c1::ADH}}


Is it a side effect of the Compensatory mechanisms?
Bradycardia{{c1::n}}
Peripheries are cold{{c1::y}}
Hypertension{{c1::n}}
Hypotension{{c1::y}}
High GFR{{c1::n}}
Low Urine Output{{c1::y}}

Why does the body have these compensatory mechanisms?
{{c1::To maintain organ perfusion}}

What happens if they don't work?
{{c1::shock}}

TYPES OF SHOCK:

Hypovolaemic shock: Due to {{c1::loss of blood volume}}
Cardiogenic shock: Due to {{c1::reduction in contractility of the heart}}
Vasogenic shock (e.g septic shock): {{c1::Due to Loss of the ability to maintain an adequate TPR}}
Obstructive shock (e.g. pulmonary embolism): due to {{c1::obstruction}}

Cause of HYPOVOLAEMIC SHOCK:
{{c1::Inadequate fluid intake or excessive fluid loss}}

Specific causes:
GI losses: {{c1::Vomiting/diarrhoea}}

Renal losses: {{c1::Polyuria}} (e.g Hyperosmolarity in diabetes, DI)

Skin losses: burns

Redistribution: {{c1::‘leaky’ capillaries}} (e.g Pancreatitis)

Haemorrhage

Causes of Hypovolaemic Haemorrhagic shock!
Trauma – penetrating or blunt

Vascular : {{c1::aneurysms, dissections, AVMs}} (3)
– E.g. Ruptured abdominal aortic {{c1::aneuyrsm}}

GI haemorrhage
– Oesphageal {{c1::varices}}
– Oesophageal or gastric {{c1::ulceration}}

Obstetric haemorrhage:
– Ruptured {{c1::ectopic pregnancy}}
– {{c1::Placenta praevia}}
– {{c1::Abruption}}

AVM=Atriovenous malformations
Placenta praevia= placenta attaches to lower part of the womb sometimes covering the cervix
Abruption=eparation of the placenta from the wall of the uterus during pregnancy

How much O2 dissolved in blood? {{c1::3}}ml/L
How much O2 does fully saturated Hb carry? {{c1::1.39}} ml O2/g
Normal Hb content of blood? {{c1::15}} g/dl
Normal O2 content of blood? {{c1::21}} ml/dl

Oxygen delivery depends on:

{{c1::The amount of oxygen in the blood}}
{{c1::The amount of blood that is pumped}}

In a haemorrhage, why is it bad that: 
blood is lost? {{c1::oxygen carrying capacity is reduced}}
Volume is lost? {{c1::cardiac output is reduced}}

What sort of iscahemia is it associated with?
Cardiac, Renal, Cerebral, GI

– Sepsis {{c1::G}}
– Acute tubular necrosis {{c1::R}}
– Infarction (MI){{c1::Card}}
– Stroke{{c1::Cer}}
– Arrhythmias{{c1::Card}}
– Angina{{c1::Card}}
– Renal failure{{c1::R}}
– Acute confusional state{{c1::Cer}}
– Gut infarction{{c1::G}}
– Cardiac failure{{c1::Card}}
Cardiac Ischaemia's telltale is {{c1::st depression}} on an ECG

Lack of oxygen for aerobic metaolism forces the cell to generate energy  by {{c1::anaerobic metabolism}}

Pyruvate + NADH » {{c1::Lactate}} + NAD+

{{c1::Lactate}} is useful as a sign of shock

So what to do to a patient in hypovolemic shock?
Restore {{c1::oxygen}} delivery by Give {{c1::Oxygen}} Give {{c1::Blood}}
Restore {{c1::circulating}} volume by Give {{c1::Fluids}}

Fluid resuscitation

{{c1::Crystalloids}} and {{c1::colloids}}
Blood products
{{c1::– Whole blood
– Red cell concentrate
– Plasma
– Platelets}}(4)

Causes of Cardiogenic shock

{{c1::– Myocardial infarction
– Myocarditis
– Severe valvular disease
– Severe arrythmias
– Pericardial effusions and tamponade}}

When do you know pateint is improving?

Blood pressure increases
Heart rate increases
Renal output increases
GFR increases
Hb concentration increases
Cardiac Output increases

{{c1::all except for HR which decreases}}

Circulatory Shock

The state in which profound and widespread reduction in the delivery of {{c1::02}} and other {{c1::nutrients}} to {{c1::tissues}}, leads firstly to {{c1::reversible}} and, if {{c1::prolonged}}, leads to irreversible cellular injury.

Caused By
1. {{c1::reduced blood volume (hypovolaemic shock)}}
2. {{c1::loss of cardiac function (cardiogenic shock)}}
3. {{c1::loss of the ability to maintain an adequate total peripheral resistance (distributive shock)}}

Decrease in blood volume following haemorrhage causes a fall in {{c1::MABP}}

{{c1::MABP}} = CO x TPR

A fall in {{c1::MABP}} following haemorrhage elicits homeostatic reflexes to minimise the fall in {{c1::MABP}}
• 3 responses

- Immediate: {{c1::Baroceptor reflex}}

- Intermediate: {{c1::Borrows fluid from the interstitial space}}

- Long-term: {{c1::Replaces fluid, plasma proteins and rbcs}}

SHORT TERM
- A haemorrhage causes a drop in arterial pressure
- BP drop detected by {{c1::reduced firing of baroceptors}}

Effect on HEART:
-{{c1::decreased}} parasympathetic cardiac activity
-{{c1::increased}} sympathetic cardiac activity
Change in both ps and s activity leads to {{c1::Increased firing of SA node to increase heart rate}}
Change in specifically sypathetic activity causes increased {{c1::cardiac muscle contractility}} which leads to an increase in {{c1::stroke volume}}.

Both Mechanisms contribute to increasing {{c1::Cardiac Output}}

Effect on VEINS:
-{{c1::increased}} sympathetic venous activity
Peripheral Veno{{c1::constriction}} which causes:
{{c1::Increased}} Venous Pressure
{{c1::Increased}} Venous return
{{c1::Increased}} EDV


Which leads to an increased {{c1::Stroke Volume}} and {{c1::Cardiac Output}}

Effects on Arteries:
Ateroconstriction ------- Increased TPR

Intermediate

The reduction in {{c1::capillary hydrostatic}} pressure favours the movement of fluid from the {{c1::interstitial}} into the {{c1::vascular space}}

• As a result, {{c1::plasma volume}} is increased (back to normal in 12 to 24 hr)
• {{c1::MABP}} is restored towards normal (blood loss up to 1L - 20% of TBV)

Fluid replacement

Following haemorrhage, the hormone {{c1::aldosterone}} is released from the adrenal cortex

{{c1::Aldosterone}} stimulates the retention of {{c1::Na+ (and water)}} by the kidneys

Following haemorrhage, {{c1::thirst}} is stimulated. {{c1::Ingestion of water}} will replace the fluid lost during the haemorrhage


Following haemorrhage, the {{c1::bone marrow}} is stimulated to
produce {{c1::red blood}} cells

Replacement of {{c1::red blood}} cells lost during the haemorrhage may take {{c1::3-4 weeks}}

Blood losses up to {{c1::20% (1L)}} can be compensated for

Hypovolaemic shock (blood loss)

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage of up to 10% of total blood volume: {{c1::fully compensated}}
• CO is {{c1::maintained}}
• MABP is {{c1::maintained}}
• PP is {{c1::maintained}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 10% and 20% of total blood volume: compensated shock
• CO {{c1::falls (reduced circulating BV)}}
• MABP is {{c1::maintained by increased TPR}}
• Pulse pressure (PP) is {{c1::reduced}}

{{c1::Cerebral (brain)}} and {{c1::coronary blood flow (heart)}} are 1initially protected from the fall in MAP (MAP>{{c1::70mmHg}})

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 20% and 30% of total blood volume
• CO {{c1::continues to fall}}
• MABP {{c1::falls}}
• PP is {{c1::not there}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage between 30% and 40% of total blood volume

• CO continues to fall
• MABP extremely low
• At about {{c1::35%}} loss of BV, MAP plateaus
- hypoxia in {{c1::brain}}
- direct stimulation of {{c1::cardiovascular centres}}
- massive{{c1::sympathetic stimulation}}

Cardiovascular response to haemorrhage above 40% of total blood volume

{{c1::Complete collapse of CVS}}

A. Progressive shock: the vicious cycle

Once haemorrhage is severe enough (and no fluid replacement is performed)
- {{c1::coronary blood flow}} falls
- reduced {{c1::coronary blood flow}} reduces myocardial {{c1::contractility}}
- reduced {{c1::cardiac output}}
- reduced {{c1::MAP}} leads to a reduction in coronary blood flow VICIOUS CYCLE
• As the shock is becoming worse at this time, it is said to be progessive stage of shock

If hypovolaemic shock remains untreated, {{c1::myocardial contractility}} falls (hypoxia)
• By {{c1::4}} hr, the Starling curve is
poor
• By {{c1::5}} hr, the Starling curve
cannot maintain life

B. Irreversible shock:

If fluid replacement is not performed in severe haemorrhage, the progressive stage of shock will soon progress into irreversible shock

• When the patient enters irreversible shock, fluid administration or other therapy is {{c1::incapable}} of saving the patient
• Initially, fluid administration will {{c1::elevate}} cardiac output during the fluid administration and for a short period afterwards
• Unfortunately, {{c1::permanent}} damage to the {{c1::tissue of the heart (reduced contractility)}} and {{c1::brain (including the cardiovascular centre in the medulla)}} is likely to have occurred
• The patient can neither control {{c1::myocardial contractility}} (reduced CO) or {{c1::vascular tone(TPR)}} and consequently {{c1::MAP}} cannot be maintained
